content: Project Looking Glass: Its Architecture and a Sneak Preview of the API

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div table tbody tr td a span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td em span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td em a span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td em span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Project Looking Glass (LG3D) exploits Java technology to bring a richer user experience to the desktop and to applications, through 3D windowing and visualization capabilities. This article covers Project Looking Glass' main features and API, its basic organization, and the functionality of important classes. You'll get an understanding of its high level architecture and where further development contributions are needed.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Project Looking Glass is an open source development project, so you can decide what areas you would like to dig into. The project supports both unmodified existing applications in a 3D space and APIs for 3D window managers and application development.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Because Project Looking Glass is a work in progress, the details specified in this article are subject to change. The APIs are not final but are continuously evolving, improving, and expanding as more developers contribute to this project. Suggestions for improvement are invited via the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p a span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: LG3D breaks past two boundaries in the world of user experience design: the 2D-ness of current desktop environments, and the way in which these desktop environments evolve. At a very high level, the project focuses on providing a solid platform for the exploration of the 3D desktop environment, and exploring creative ideas by developing 3D window managers (SceneManagers) and applications on top of the platform.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Currently, Sun focuses on providing core functionality to kickstart the 3D exploration and refine the initial platform. The current platform supports the following key features:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Initial set of core APIs for building 3D widget sets

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Java technology is the primary development language because of the productivity gains it brings, its language safety features, and the rich set of supporting APIs it provides. These benefits promote more aggressive exploration of the new 3D desktop frontier. In the future, C++ bindings will be provided so that existing native applications can access the features of the LG3D platform.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The LG3D API leverages the Java 3D API and provides additional features, including an animation system (to simplify writing rich user-experience applications) and APIs for 3D window manager development and interaction. The Java 3D API provides a set of object-oriented interfaces that support a simple, high-level programming model that can be used to build, render, and control the behavior of 3D objects and visual environments. Because LG3D is built on top of the Java 3D API, the platform leverages all these favorable features.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: A feature subset of the Java 3D API is exposed to the client side. This enables the future possibility of running the same client application program in a resource-limited environment like a set-top box or car navigation system.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The client-server Java 3D Scene Graph software allows multiple processes to share the same virtual 3D universe. This technology allows the platform to execute a LG3D-aware 3D application in a separate process (even on a remote machine), while it displays a 3D user interface integrated within the single virtual universe with which the user interacts. Like the X client-server model, this enables clean isolation among applications and the platform.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The platform provides an abstraction layer for communication protocol. The first developer's release uses RMI for convenience.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p i span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: here does not imply client and server machines connected through a network but rather processes typically running on the same machine. A client is an application that issues requests to render its user interface. Typically, the machine runs a single server that receives rendering requests from clients and constructs the screen image.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Animation typically operates on a scene graph per frame. A mechanism to execute animation on the server side is provided, so that client and server do not need to communicate per frame. The client specifies types of animation with parameters, such as duration.The platform provides several predefined animations. In addition, animation can be realized by leveraging animation support in model loaders. With those features, the limitations regarding server-side behavior is not considered critical.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td b span
content: Existing Application Integration -- The Abstraction Layer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The abstraction layer can be roughly divided into two major areas: the Foundation Window System (FWS) module, and the Native Window representation module.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The FWS module provides the integration with the underlying window system, including application visual capture and event delivery integration. The module includes a set of interfaces for implementation of different kind of plug-ins for a native window system.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Currently there are two implementations, the X11 version and the AWT version. The X Window System (commonly X11 or X) is a windowing system for bitmap displays. It is the standard graphical interface on UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems like Linux, and is available for most modern operating systems. The X11 integration allows X applications to be run and displayed within the LG3D platform. The AWT version allows the platform to run operating systems that support required Java platform and Java 3D extension versions (such as Solaris and Windows), but without support for applications running in the native window system. This module resides under the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The Native Window representation module sits on top of the FWS, and provides abstracted representation of the native window application's visual aspects.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The LG3D platform's high-level architecture is illustrated in Figure 2, showing the X11 integration. An unmodified X Client Application communicates with the X Server, which is enhanced with the X Client Capture functionality. This enhanced X Server captures the client's visual representation and sends it to the LG3D Display Server, which manages rendering of the 3D space, using the Java 3D platform. For LG3D-aware 3D application development, the platform provides LG3D Java libraries that expose the Java API. The libraries communicate with the Display Server for constructing 3D visuals and exchanging events.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The Scene Manager resides in the Display Server process. It communicates with the Display Server control and implements a policy regarding 3D application user interaction and arrangement in the 3D space.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span

content: The Scene Manager takes over the role of window manager for a 3D scene, since typical LG3D-aware 3D application user interfaces have unique shapes not limited to a window shape. The Scene Manager interacts with the user and applications. It implements management policy for applications running in the environment and is responsible for arranging those in the 3D space.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Scene Manager design is a major area of future exploration. In order to stimulate many ideas, an initial framework for componentized Scene Manager technology has been provided. In the implementation, attention has been paid to two-and-a-half dimension as well as full three dimension experiences under the same abstraction. The following list shows the key Scene Manager components, along with its abstract class or interface name.

html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: is the main body of the LG3D Display Server module that is responsible for all the rendering that happens in the 3D space. The communication includes obtaining display-specific information like the field of view, setting view transform, and specifying the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: interface. The communication includes adding and removing a

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: is invoked with an argument set to true,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: eventually receives server-side representation of the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: then in turn passes the object to the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object. Note that the native window abstraction layer also provides a

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object as the top level object with which Scene Manager interacts. In this way, there is no difference between an LG3D-aware 3D application and a 3D-mapped native window.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: is a key foundation for implementing the user interaction and application navigation capabilities of Scene Manager. It is also useful for achieving two-and-a-half dimension desktop experience. The application container is a subclass of

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: and is specialized for hosting applications, such as

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: An application container usually leverages the 3D layout manager to implement easy-to-access application arrangements in the container. It is key to leveraging the 3D space when arranging the applications. Based on a Scene Manager implementation exercise, the 3D layout manager turned out to be a flexible platform for achieving the goal while allowing implementations to be componentized.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: A single Scene Manager can host multiple application containers. The Scene Manager implements the concept of the current application container. It receives a

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object when a new LG3D-aware application is activated. The current container can be switched dynamically. This feature is typically used to implement virtual desktop switching.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: In the LG3D 3D desktop environment, the background is more than just a static image behind application windows. It actually defines the 3D environment with which the user can interact and where application containers can be positioned.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The Background can comprise any 3D geometry as it is a subclass of

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: , to which any geometry can be added and any behavior can be integrated.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: In addition to setting up the geometry to render on the background, the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object also hosts application containers. The object usually keeps a reference to a

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object that is passed through the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: object to manage application containers including obtaining and switching current. Since

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: , the background object can place it anywhere in the 3D scene. It also can allow the user to handle multiple application containers by switching the current application container and changing the view so that the current one remains accessible to the user.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: For more details, you may want to check out the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: class, which is a simple example implementation of background with comments.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Light is also componentized. Instead of a static global light that the default implementation provides (StandardGlobalLights), you can develop lights that dynamically change angle and color based on time of the day, for example. Or, a Scene Manager may want to use lighting effects to provide an alert or focus to the user.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: class implements policies on how cursor is displayed. It provides Scene Manager hooks for the addition and removal of

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: objects, and a hook for positioning the current cursor. For example, in the default implementation

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: , the maximum distance of the current cursor from the user's point of view is limited to a certain value so that the cursor will appear to the user at a reasonable size. Without this policy, a cursor could be drawn so far away on the surface of the background that the user would have difficulty finding it.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td b span
content: Interaction Events Between Frame3D and Scene Manager

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The generic event system is employed as the main communication method between

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: and Scene Manager, to achieve both loosely coupled componentization and the interplay of a rich set of user actions and requests between them.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: This area needs more investigation. Currently, a few adhoc events have been introduced to achieve the initial demo features.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The 2D application integration framework can be roughly divided into two major areas: the Foundation Window System (FWS) module and the Native Window representation module.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span b span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td div span span
html body text table tbody tr td a span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The FWS module provides the integration with the underlying window system, including application visual capture and event delivery integration. Since these interfaces are not a part of the client API and not visible to client application developers, this document does not cover any details.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The Native Window representation module sits on top of the FWS, and provides abstracted representation of native window application's visual aspect. It is in the

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: package. Its two primary design goals are to

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Allow a pluggable Look and Feel

tag: html body text table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Encapsulate complexity around native window capture and communication

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The classes in this package attempt to abstract and hide all the complexity around the native application visual capture, as well as necessary communication with the application side. Figure 8 illustrates the relationships among the major classes.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: is the top level class with which

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: interacts. It extends Frame3D and behaves just like another LG3D-aware 3D application. It also implements the methods declared in

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: , which are used for the native 2D window manager to give notifications about status changes, and so on. The implementation, in turn, uses

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: interface to communicate back to the native window manager, so that it can perform actions on the 2D applicationassociated with this object.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: defines the native window's appearance and visual texture. At this level, typically, window decoration is constructed. The current implementation includes

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: exist to hide all the complexity related to native window capture support. Texture is used for presenting captured 2D window surfaces in the 3D space, but it has a size limitation that is sometimes smaller than maximum 2D window size. To deal with large 2D window capture, we use composite multiple textures created from a set of

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: . The details are hidden under these classes.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div b span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: , you can develop your own window decoration. If you want a native window representation this is not on a simple quad ï¿½ on a wavy sheet, for example &ndash you will need to implement a version of

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: that supports the shape you want.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: An API to map multiple native window representations on surfaces of a single object is under development, which will be used to put another view on the back side of the window.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div b span
content: A Quick Tour of the Project Looking Glass Source Code

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Now that you've learned the basic architecture of Project Looking Glass and understand its important classes, you are invited to download the code and to begin contributing your programming skills. To work on this project, you need to be a

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: member, which is free upon registration. Then you can download and install a working version of the software and the source code.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p code span
